In mathematics, an outer measure Î¼ on n-dimensional Euclidean space
'R' n is called 'Borel regular' if the following two conditions hold:

* Every Borel set B â 'R' n is Î¼-measurable in the sense of
  CarathÃ©odory's criterion: for every A â 'R' n,
:: \mu (A) = \mu (A \cap B) + \mu (A \setminus B).
* For every set A â 'R' n (which need not be Î¼-measurable)
  there exists a Borel set B â 'R' n such that
  A â B and Î¼(A) = Î¼(B).

An outer measure satisfying only the first of these two requirements is called a
Borel measure, while an outer measure satisfying only the second requirement is
called a regular measure.

The Lebesgue outer measure on 'R' n is an example of a Borel
regular measure.

It can be proved that a Borel Regular measure, although introduced here as an
outer measure (only countably ''sub''additive), becomes a full measure
(countably additive) if restricted to the Borel sets.
